title: Mono adapter for drawer slide in kitchen cabinet

description.text: These are replacement parts for kitchen cabinets made years ago by a company called Merillat, which is, I believe, acquired by Masco.  Part of the drawer slide is this part, called a "mono adapter".  The sides of the part tend to wear out over the course of years of use.  It turns out that you can order replacements for these if you email someone at mascocabinetry.com.  It's $10 for a pack of 4, plus shipping.  However, I'd already made a model and printed some out.  The replacements I printed worked great.

Printed the "right way up" as shown in the image of the part.  I added support structure.  Printed in ABS with 2 side borders and 3 layers top/bottom solid.  Also 30% infill.  I used support material because of the "slot" on the bottom and mechanically removed the support material later.  You could modify the model and just remove the slot... I think that might work too.

A scan of a Shishi - a guardian lion statue from Wat Bowonniwet, a buddhist temple site in Bangkok, Thailand.

This is one of a few 123D Catch captures I made on a recent trip the Thailand and Cambodia. Though it could be cleaned up a little more I did make it into a printable mesh in Netfabb. Please post images if you print. 
Printed at .27mm layer height with support on my replicator.

Made for use with a #8 (about 4mm) threaded rod with slots for the bolts to fit into. I'm using one squared and one rounded for each clamp, a wing nut on one end for tightening and a hex nut to keep one end in place.  
One side is rounded to fit into a rounded hole (the enclosure's floor) and the other squared to sit flush against the surface it's being clamped to. Will post pictures once it's up and ready.  
Made specifically for an enclosure I built for my printer, needed to put the enclosure on a surface that was much too small and figured this would easily clamp it securely in case the vibration moved it at all. I also plan on putting the kitchen mesh (normally used in cupboard for dishes) between the surface and the enclosure to ensure there isn't any slippage.

1 - Rounded
1 - Squared
1 - #8 (about 4mm) threaded rod
2 - #8 hex nuts
2 - #8 wing nuts Put the bolts into the fitted hex holes, you may need to use a leatherman as it was a little bit of a tight fit for me. Screw the rod through to form your clamp, you can optionally use #4-1/2in screws to affix the clamp to the surface of what you're trying to clamp as these were made just to hold something larger from falling or slipping - they don't work well as clamps otherwise ;P

title: Beinschutz für eingeklappe Spikes an einer Krücke

description.text:
Der Body wird mittels der Bügel an der Krücke (Gehhilfe) so befestigt, dass die Spikes in der Schale zu liegen kommen und die Umgebung nicht verletzen können. Weiter kann optional an einer oder beiden Seiten ein Supporter montiert werden, der das zuziehen einer Türe mittels Krücke vereinfacht. Auf dem Foto sind handelsübliche Türpuffer verbaut.  
Auf den Fotos ist V. 3.0 abgebildet. Das CAD-Bild zeigt die neuere, stärkere Version, welche runtergelden wird.  
PS: Ich kann leider kein Englich. Wenn du Lust hast, diesen Artikel zu Übersetzen, wäre ich dir Dankbar. Übersetzung am einfachsten an meinen Kontakt. Vielen Dank!

I wanted to design a way to attach my calipers to my Prusa Mendel. Therefore I made this thing to slide onto the top of the printer's frame and house the calipers. 
The object slides onto the top two M8 threaded rods of the prusa mendel frame.

• Print out with something higher than 30% infill. I printed it at a layer height of 0.2mm, but that is optional.
  • Slide the part onto the top frame of the prusa mendel (Either side is fine)
  • Slide calipers into designated slot
  • Be excited

description.text: Here is my story. I am a third year engineering student at Arizona State, and unfortunately, I have become a victim of racial profiling (I am a US citizen) that put my father in jeopardy of being deported. I love doing what I do (sharing my passion for 3d printing) and unfortunately I will not be able to continue this passion. I am debating whether I should fight back and file a civil suit, however, I currently do not have the funds to do so but if you have a friend who is an immigration lawyer, please contact me via the messaging app built into Thingiverse. Also, if you feel compelled or are facing or know someone who is facing a similar story, CONTACT me as I would like to build a case. Also, any donations would greatly expedite things. I have my PayPal account linked to my Thingiverse account so it is convenient.

title: Pistol Grip Camera Gun w Flashlight Attachment

description.text: Tired of covering the little microphone hole on your digital camera when filming?  Try my CameraGun, it even has an atachment you can put an led flashlight into.  Check out my youtube channel to see this get printed!

It has two parts. This wont be hard to figure out. You do have to have a small bolt to attach the camera to the gun, I used an old camera mount knob. There is an upload for lefties, and an upload for righties. Without the camera, the grip still makes a nice pistol-like flashlight. DO NOT MAKE OUT OF DARK PLASTIC. ALWAYS MAKE OUT OF NEON or BRIGHT COLOR PLASTIC. You really don't want someone to think you are pointing a real gun at people. http://youtu.be/lVMLnWmTqTY

description.text: This duct takes the good 40mm Fan Duct V3 from Ultibots and optimizes it to not require printing supports, and to evenly distribute the cooling flow across the width of the gap. It also gives more directed flow toward the printed parts at the end of the print nozzle.

Print without support. I printed mine at 0.20 mm on a 0.35 nozzle. 3 perimeters and 3 solid top & bottom layers. The fan mount is taken straight from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34387. The fan mount is also the belt clamps. 18 March 2013 - Note: I have sized the holes that mount to the fan to be tapped for an M3 bolt so it does not need a nut. These holes have a 2.5 mm diameter, so if you want to use a nut to hold your fan on, just drill them to the diameter you need. 04 June 2013 - Added v2 stl that makes the exit slots 5 mm longer by request. The width of the slots was reduced slightly to keep the total exit area the same. I have not tried printing this version, so let me know if this version works! 30 June 2013 - Added the stp files of each version (I used the 203 version of the step exporter in Alibre, as opposed to the 214 version. I don't know the difference)

title: TARDIS Battery Base for Joule Thief

description.text: Light up your TARDIS off of a single AA or AAA battery! This design runs off of a joule thief to light up your LEDs off of a single 1.5v battery. It can even run off of "dead" batteries that don't have enough juice to power other devices. This does require some soldering in tight spaces, so it may not be for the faint of heart.

You'll need to know the basics of how to make a joule thief. A great instructible can be found here. The center circle is sized for some toroids I ordered from Amazon. Other than the materials needed for the joule thief, you may also want to pick up some battery springs and plates. The ones I used can be found here on Amazon. And, finally, you will need to find a SPDT (single pole, double throw) switch and jumper wire. You may also want to have a hot glue gun and glue on-hand to secure things into place and help prevent possible short circuits. Once you're comfortable with how the joule thief goes together, you're ready to proceed.
  • Solder some 1" jumper wires (x4) to the positive (plate) and negative (springs) battery spings/plates. Try to keep the soldering as light as possible to make it easier to insert into the channel for the springs/plates.
  • Solder the other end of the 1" jumper wire on the battery springs to the outer pins on the SPDT switch.
  • Solder another 1" jumper wire to the center pin on the SPDT switch.
  • Solder the jumper wire from the center pin on the SPDT switch to one of the single wires from the joule thief.
  • Solder the jumper wires from the battery plates (positive side) to the double twisted wire on the joule thief.
  • Insert the battery springs into the 1mm channel on the negative (-) side on both battery sides.
  • Insert the battery plates into the 1mm channel on the positive (+) side on both battery sides.
  • Push the SPDT switch into the hole in the base wall on the negative side.
  • Prepare ~6" of jumper wire to be used to run to the LEDs in the TARDIS.
  • Finish wiring/soldering the transistor, resistor, and 6" jumper wire on the joule thief. I highly recommend twisting wires together before soldering and constantly checking to make sure everything works. The less you have to undo, the better!
  • (Optional) Hot glue the contacts on all the connections and add some extra glue to help hold things down. You may also want to add some glue in the hole that the SPDT switch is placed in. The tension from the jumper wires may be enough to hold it in place really well, but a little extra hot glue never hurts. Once the hot glue has cooled off and dried, cut away any glue on or above the 1mm shelf that runs around the center of the base.
  • Place the cover over the center of the base (to hide all the circuitry), but make sure your 6" jumper wire is aligned in one of the notches to run into the main cavity of the TARDIS. You may have to sand the edges of the cover so that it will press-fit down onto the 1mm shelf and stay secure without bowing. It's design to be friction-fitted, and I would advise against using any glue to hold it in place in case you need to fix/solder/glue stuff under the hood.
  • Position the LED or LEDs you wish to use inside the TARDIS cavity. A 5mm LED seems to easily slide into the lamp shade at the top and helps hold any other LEDs up and in place. I wouldn't recommend any more than 3 LEDs just to keep things from getting too dim (you are running on a "dead" battery after all!).
    • The circuit is designed so that it only runs on a single AA or AAA at a time. I'm not an electrical engineer or anything, but something about mixed voltages and remaining capacitance seems like it might not be optimal. So just leave only one battery in there at a time. Assuming only one battery, when you move the switch to the other side to turn the circuit off. Also make sure you don't glue the TARDIS body to the base and make sure there's just enough slack in the jumper wire in the cavity so that you can open the TARDIS to swap out batteries (see picture).

I recently got Ninjaflex extruding, and created this as a test to see what type of properties it has.  Lots of overhanging bits (but you can get away with no support) and small extrusions.  No reason you need to use Ninjaflex though, ABSPLA should work just fine.  Just not as squishy.  
I'd had a lot of trouble in the past getting Ninjaflex to properly load into my machine.  At that time I was unable to adjust my 'filament load' temperature:  I presume it was set around 220 deg.  But after upgrading to Sailfish firmware that ability was made available:  Filament load @ 240 degrees works a-ok.  
What did I learn from the print? Need to crank up retraction:  Lots of stringing I had to later remove, reminds me of nylon in that regard.  
Modeled in Maya.  Started out as a dodecahedron, became... something else ;)

Sliced in Simplify3d & printed on Makerbot Replicator (1) with Sailfish firmware using these settings:
  • Black Ninjaflex filament.
  • 200 micron layer height, 2 shells, 4 roof, 4 floor, 20% infill.
  • 30mm/sec print (per online recommendations), 120mm/sec travel.
  • Extruded @ 240 deg on blue painters tape with no supports or raft.

This configuration contains 4 gears and frame components that fit together snuggly and spin freely. You can either download the parts and print them yourself, or buy the parts here: http://www.gotime.us/store/c1/Featured_Products.html This kit contains all of the Gear Frame parts. With these parts, you can build any Gear Frame or Gear Time projects. Note: the tframe part and the t2frame part are the same part. Older directions (written before the t1frame and the t3frame were created) only used 1 kind of frame part (which did not need a number for designation.) Later, as new parts were added to the kit, a number was added to the frame part names. Ah, I just love backward compatibility issues.

Step 1) Print out: 4x tgear
4x taxle
8x tframe
8x tbearing
8x tcap Step 2) Take 4 taxles and 4 tcaps and press one cap into the notched end of each taxle. The notches should line up to form a 'T' and fit snuggly (see pictures to make sure that the parts are aligned correctly.) Step 3) Take 4 tbearings and slip one onto each taxel and slide them down the taxle until they come to rest against the tcap. Step 4) Take 2 tframes and place 2 taxles into the holes of each tframe so that the tbearings will the hole completely. The notched side of the tframe should be facing away from the tcaps. Step 5) Take 2 more tframes and place them in the taxles so that the 4 tframes from a square. the notched side of the second pair of tframes should be facing towards the other tframes. The notches should lock the tframes into right angel corners. Step 6) Take 4 tgears and slide them into the taxles so they come to rest against the tframes. The teeth of the tgear should interlock. Step 7) Take the last 4 tbearings and slide them onto the taxles so they come to rest against the tgear. Step 8) Take two more tframes and place them onto the tbearings so that they look like a '=' sign. The notches in the tframes should be facing away from the tgear. Step 9) Take the last 2 tframes and place them on the taxles so that they form a square (just as in step 5.) The notched side of the second pair of tframes should be facing towards the other tframes. The notches should lock the tframes into right angels. Step 10) Take the last 4 tcaps and press one cap into the open notched end of each taxle. The notches should line up to form a 'T' and fit snuggly (see pictures to make sure that the parts are aligned correctly.) These tcaps should hold the entire structure together.

Drill a same-size hole on the right side, matching placement and hole diameter as the pivot post on the left side.  Use stainless hardware to bolt 4 of these to the frame.  Use Wingnuts on the tightening flange to perform no-tool assembly.  Use Washers where necessary.  
DISCLAIMER: Do not put a child into the trailer with this modification!  Use this modification for hauling things at your own risk to yourself, your trailer, and anything being hauled!

remixed_from.title: Prusa Mendel I2 Foot for Spring Feet

description.text: This part slips on to the vertex foot of a reprap prusa mendel I2. It helps isolate mechanical noise and vibrations. Apparently, after a while the spring part bends a little. I made the gap larger to allow for this.

I have a mini mill but my existing vice is just junk. This milling vice is a highly functional and was in my budget. (Steel version on amazon for reference: http://amzn.to/28MwWtd) The part that makes this design strong is the steel plates cut to size and glued in plate to distribute forces. Check out the picture of the tin can I was able to smash. I've attached a printable layover sheet for the face plates. Another cool thing about this vice is that you can use in reverse for inside clamping of large objects.
Also, the main lead screw doesn't move in and out as the slide moves which makes the mill handle underneath more accessible.
http://youtu.be/HC69pqXPNkQ

I printed all parts at 30% infill with ABS. I used ABS glue to hold all the parts together. UPDATE: Hot glue works better. Painting this thing was a lot of work. I was just trying to cover up the red portions of abs glue but I stupidly painted onto surfaces I would later attempt to glue metal plates to. On the bright side, using abs glue and sandable primer to build up surfaces I was able to get a nice finish. If you just want to have plastic faces I have included models for those. You don't need to print the 'face' parts if you are going to use steel plates. Do everything you can to prevent warping on the base parts. The bottom of these parts will be a working surface so if they warp the slide will wiggle in use. During final assembly of the lead screw I threaded the nylock nut onto the rod past the end and used a hammer to mar the rod threads on the outside. Then I unscrewed the nylock nut until it stuck on the marred end, locking it in place. I recommend using two jam nuts to lock the other side in place. The vice mounts are designed for 5/16" bolts. UPDATED Shopping List: (1) Nylock hex nut 1/2"-13
(1) 12" of 1/2"-13 threaded rod
(1) 16 ga, 6" x 18" steel plate (available at Lowes.)
(4) Jam Nut 1/2"-13 (Two for the slide, two for double nutting the rod on the back side of the vice)
(1) 2.5" long 5/16-18 bolt (for handle)
(2) 5/16"-18 nuts (for double nutting the handle) http://youtu.be/HC69pqXPNkQ

title: OnePlus One Cellphone and Ringke Fusion Case Stand

description.text:
This is a basic cellphone stand for the OnePlus One phone with the Ringke Fusion case. If you are looking for a case, I have to say that the Ringke fusion case is the best one I have found so far. The OnePlus will fit on this stand without having the Ringke Fusion case, but it will be a little loose. Maybe I will make one for the bare OnePlus One some day....  
I have embossed the text - I think it looks OK that way (see screen shots). There is a cutout for the volume rockers, and the tabs which retain the phone are spaced correctly so they do not cover any of the screen image.  
I hope the one other person in the world who has a OnePlus One, and the Ringke Fusion case, and a 3D printer, find these files useful!!!

I have uploaded 6 configs. There are 3 tilt angles - 15 degrees, 25 degrees, and 40 degrees. I find that the 15 is perfect for my original intention of using the cellphone as a rearview mirror at work -so people don't sneak up on me. It is also about the steepest angle you can use and not have the phone want to fall out (use at your own risk). It is also great for straight-on viewing - like laying in bed and having the stand on your stomach for watching movies - or on a car dashboard while waiting to pick up your kids ;>)  I would NEVER suggest using this for cell-navigation in a car, as it would not hold the phone very well.  
The 25 degree is a good general purpose angle. Finally, there is the 40 degree, which is really flat - but still easy to put the phone in and out. I would use this one on a plane, where you have the tray-table up close and you have to angle the phone way back to see the screen.  
Finally, there are 2 variations of each. The shell version cuts out the backside and leaves a 2.5mm wall thickness everywhere. I like this version - it's strong enough and light weight. I have the solid version also, for those who want a flat bottom (maybe you can add non-slip rubber to it...).  
I tried this with slic3r and cura with poor results - I really never got my print settings down with these programs. Simplify3D worked flawlessly on a TAZ4 the first time. I use rafts, as the early attempts peeled off at the corners during printing (with slic3r and cura). I also use supports, which come out easily afterwards (it only needs them underneath the flat areas). I have printed all 3 shell versions without problems. Print time was a little over 6 hours.   
One more thing - it looks like thingiverse took my stl files and made pictures out of them. I would not print the files in that orientation. Put the model down flat on the bed, just the same as how you would use the finished part.  
(updated 3/1/15 - converted files to mm)

title: Arc Reactor Overlay for EL Panel

description.text: I built an "arc reactor" out of an exploded LED flashlight and a plastic bottle a few years back, but for a while I've been thinking that if the light source was electroluminescent, the light distribution would be more even and it wouldn't stick out of my chest so obviously. I've worked with EL wire before, and when I saw that cutting EL panels into custom shapes was even more difficult, I decided to take an easier route.

Get a 10x10cm EL panel and an inverter to drive it.
The overlay is only half a millimeter thick to keep it about as flexible as the EL panel is. I've found that black ABS parts only a layer or two thick are completely opaque, whereas thicker parts printed in other colors still let some light through. Print this part in the most opaque plastic you have.
The tabs on the backside have no support, so you'll have to separate them with a blade. They're not as springy as I hoped, but they hold the panel in just fine.
Run a velcro or elastic strap through the sides and start wearing it!
I've added a blank version if you want to make a different generation arc reactor.

title: NEMA17 Extruder for 1.75mm softer, flexible Filament

description.text:

title: Satellite Receiver mount for 250 size QuadCopters

description.text:
I'm using this to mount a Spektrum satellite receiver to an Argonaut AQ250 QuadCopter but it should be useful for many quads and other small receivers.  
Satellite receivers are great for mini quads, but because they're so small, the antennas are often very close to the frame. This is a problem with carbon frames and it may affect your range.  
You could try mounting your receiver hanging partially off the edge of the frame to keep the antennas away from the carbon, but this would make it more susceptible to impact damage.  
This light weight mount is designed to attach to the frame with two small screws and locates your receiver away from the carbon panels while keeping it relatively safe within the confines of the frame.

I used Openscad

This is an approximately 1:385 scale model of an Imperial German P-Class zeppelin as used in World War I. As these airships varied individually, it most closely replicates LZ 87 in German Imperial Army service. The primary reference used for dimensions and shapes was "Zeppelin p-class: Description of design features and differences between the ships" by Thorsten Brand.  
At this scale, it is 42.5 centimeters (16.7 inches) in length.

Print all five modules at a desired layer thickness (best between 0.1 and 0.3 mm). Use the featured picture on this page as a guide for assembly.

  • Modules 1-3 nest easily inside one another fore-to-aft, but care must be taken to correctly clock them on assembly. Make sure the fore-to-aft longeron details line up, particularly on Module 2. The cars on Modules 1 and 3 set the bottom of the model and can be used to define the center plane for clocking.

  • Module 4 is an adaptor with a flat, sheer end and a beveled end; the sheer end goes into the notch on the aft end of Module 3. Module 5 nests on top of Module 4 and is clocked to Module 3.

  • The included .png file is a series of templates for making struts out of layered paper. This is incredibly optional and left as an exercise for the builder.

My second entry for the Develop3D robot design contest.
This is inspired by the really silly robots in the 1930's movie serials.
My intent was a robot to hold a sign for

This is a Union-class DropShip in Battletech mapsheet scale (~1:909). This means it's quite small in relation to BattleMech miniatures, but it works as a map token. In particular, this model follows the look of the Union as seen in the original Technical Readout: 3025 publication. The Union-class design is copyright of Catalyst Game Labs, LLC.

Print at your desired layer thickness. Various files are offered for your use:

  • all_up_supported prints the entire DropShip as a monolithic part and is enclosed. It looks the best (assuming it prints right), is the easiest to make, and also takes up the most material since it's not hollow.

  • door_fixed and leg_fixed are piece-parts for the landing gear doors and legs respectively. They go with either:

  • hull_fixed, which has the same "solid" hull as all_up, and
  • hollow_fixed, which has a cut-out in the middle to save on material and make it easier to remove from the print bed.

title: Sausage Stuffer Kit 16mm - For KitchenAid Mixers - Requires Food Grinder Kit* - ONE TIME USE ONLY

description.text:
I received the Food Grinder Kit for our KitchenAid as a gift for Christmas. I printed the Sausage Stuffer in PLA and used it to stuff sausages today and it worked great (well - pretty good, more later). First a word of safety - You cannot clean this good enough after the first use to ever use again. Don't even try. Just drop it in the compost bin dirty and print another in 6 months when you attempt this again. (I live in Seattle, we have commercial grade composting at the curb - my PLA goes right in the bin when it is over its useful lifetime). DO NOT USE MORE THAN ONE TIME. I could only find casing for the 16mm size so I didn't design a 8mm stuffer, I don't think this will matter to anyone. I tried grinding the meat, mixing the spices then stuffing the sausages - don't try this with this kit! What a pain! The ground meat will not feed itself through the grinder, it just sits there. You basically have to press it through, not fun. What does work - mix cubed meat with spices and any other ingredients and feed this into the grinder. You won't even have to press it, it will just feed itself. Far easier, but probably a little courser mix.
  • The published version is slightly shorter than the images of my prototype, also it has a thinner flange.
    • Hope this helps someone!

title: Stand for Note 4 and Qi charger to provide bedside night clock

description.text:
My eyesight is not what it was and I need a display with large numerals for my night time bedside clock to be able to tell the time without my glasses.
For several years I used a Galaxy Note (1) for this duty. Propped up on a 3D printed stand, and plugged into the charger. Then the Note died and I invested in a Note 4. Then realised that this could be adapted to work with a QI charger...
Hence this stand which positions the Note 4 in the 'correct' charging position.
The Qi charging pad is from here: http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/251282527754?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1497.l2649
The bracket was designed in MOI and printed on a Robox using Polymakr PolyMax PLA.

I think because the stand has no horizontal base it is particularly difficult to keep from lifting from the build plate. I found it necessary to use a brim - in Robox terms a brim of 8 - I guess about 12 mm even with PLA.
I couldn't keep it flat using ABS.

title: Sanguino open case with fan and wire clamps

description.text:
A simple Sanguino case with a fan and wire clamps for each side. No lid, open case type. The fan is offset slightly to the pololu and mosfets area. There are two versions:
-the standard version with straight molex connectors (3mm clearance around the board)
and
-a wider version for 90 degrees angle molex connectors (17mm clearance around the board) which require more room around the board (files with "Molex90" prefix).

Basically you only need screws for the board and fan only, all other components can be easily thermo-welded if you lack the required screws. Actually the board itself can also be thermo-welded with 3mm filament, if you bend its ends to hold the board in place. All holes are 3mm for 3mm filament.
Print 1xBase 1xBorder and 1xFan Holder. If you find the wire clamps usefull, print 2xClamp also.
The fan angle is adjustable and it will fit any 40mm fan. 12V rails can be found on the Sanguino boards, between the motor connectors.

title: Parametric keycap puller
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Yet another keycap puller, this time in OpenSCAD.  Use this to remove 18mm Cherry style keycaps without damaging the stem or stabilizers.  You don't want to break your fancy keyboard while removing Hot Pocket and Cheetos crumbs, do you?

Use the included STL or generate your own from the SCAD. The STL assumes 18mm width and depth for the caps, and 2mm clearance to shove the grabber tines through the gaps between the keys. The 1mm lip of the grabber portion may be a little too wide, making it difficult or impossible to insert between the keys. The edge can be easily trimmed to size with a knife, or the SCAD parameter "catch_thickness" adjusted down until it barely fits. .scad also has an optional fillet to give some more strength to the tines, and optional text wrap (requires module write.scad).

author: endar

description.text:
The Chandra X-ray telescope was launched by NASA in 1999. Now with 3D printing you can have your very own tiny little Chandra to add to your collection of orbiting observatories! To learn more about Chandra, check out http://chandra.si.edu
and
http://chandra.si.edu/learn_cxc.html

Printed at 0.1mm layer height, 8% infill, 2 perimeters.  Take a piece of 3mm filament (or dowel) about 6mm long and glue into the centering holes. Align the parts like in the photos.  
The version that looks more photorealistic was made by doing a little prep work before gluing together with CA.  Loosely ball up a piece of Al foil and smooth it back out again. Secure it around the cylinder with some glue joining the seam with a little CA.  Trim off the excess and smooth it down.  I started with silver PLA but sprayed the base with silver metallic spray paint.  The gold trim on the base is a "Ready Gold Leaf" product from the craft store (sprayed with "matte finish" after finished applying to keep it stuck on). In the small top piece there are a few small supports that can optionally be removed.  I used the silver spray paint on all parts before the foils and a silver leafing pen to do touch ups after the foils were applied and before gluing together.  For the solar panels I used blue T-Glase but black works well also.  
Update for the foiled version:  Instead of Aluminum foil use the thin foil from the craft store  that is often used like tissue in a gift bag.  Ball it up and flatten out to make crinkles. Use good old rubber cement to attach it to the main body.  Apply to back of foil and to the tube, let dry, then wrap as best you can. Trim off excess.  After it looks okay and any loose foil is glued down with CA then attach the other parts to cylinder with a short piece of filament with a drop of CA (test fit first).  I glue the hatch on last with CA.  Then spray a light coating of Matte Finish over the gold trim to keep it stuck and prevent oxidation.  Attach the solar panels last (glue not needed - plus if they break you can easily replace the panels if not glued).

The TFG500 Quad is based loosely on the Spyda500 quad on this site. It uses 1/2" Sch40 PVC or 22mm OD carbon fiber arms. I recommend printing in ABS. It features a 30.5mm x 30.5mm mounting pattern for flight controllers on top and a 80x80 vibration mounts for a gimbal on the lower plate. There are 4 ESC mounts that use zip ties on the upper plate. The design requires the following metric hardware:
(QTY 6) 3x8mm bolts
(QTY 4) 3x35mm bolts
(QTY 4) 3mm nylock nuts
(QTY 8) 3mm self-tapping screws If you want, the holes can be drilled out to 1/8" for SAE bolts:
(QTY 6) 6-32x1/2" bolts
(QTY 4) 6-32x1 1/2" bolts
(QTY 4) 6-32 nylock nuts
(QTY 8) 8# self-tapping screws I've added two options for landing gear. The long leg slides through the long leg gear pad and stands 123mm (~5") tall. The short version doesn't need the gear pad and stands 55mm (~2") tall. The short and long versions use (QTY 16) 3x16mm metric bolts or (QTY 16) 6-32x5/8" SAE bolts.

Print one upper, one lower and 4 motor mounts.   
Cut 22mm carbon tubing or 1/2" PVC to 155mm.   
Fasten the upper plate to the lower plate using the four longer bolts for the center 4 fastener holes. Use the shorter bolts for the outer holes, taking care not to strip the plastic.   
Use a self tapping screw on each end of the arms, the shafts should be 193mm from outer edge of the motor mount to the inside of the 25mm wide mounting block.   
The motor mounts can also be glued or zip tied on.

title: Dial Indicator mount for Lathe Tool holder

description.text:
Mount a dial indicator into a quick change tool holder.  No need to mount a magnetic base to your lathe.  
It holds a standard round indicator with a 1/4" x 1" lug on the back.  
Set up the tool holder on your lathe's center line just once.  Easily center things in your 4 jaw chuck.

Print it fairly solid.  I printed mine in ABS at 90% infill.  
Dial indicator fits in the rectangular hole.  A 1/4" bolt secures the indicator in place.  I used a 1/4"-20 screw 1/2" long.  I just screwed it in place.  No nut was required.  
Mount then inserts into your quick change tooling just like any cutting tool.  
Set the height of the indicator piston to your lathe's center line.  
The holder is .42" tall and 3" long.  The extra length is so that it can be used on small 7x mini lathes without using up all the cross-slide travel.  
This fits into my A2Z quick change toolholders and should easily fit into larger tool holders.  
Sketchup model included.

comments.text: Nice derivative post! :-) I didn't want to dedicate a whole tool holder to just the indicator so that's why I made the models for and printed the QCTP holder too... I'm still not 100% happy with my model, but I'm probably 98% with it. I actually think I'm going to cast one out of aluminum next time I fire up the foundry but need to print one with the size enlarged to account for the shrink factor first...

title: Magnesium, Copper, Water and Alum Spiral Battery

description.text:
Make your own galvanic battery! Output voltage will be around 1.5 volts (the amperage will vary depending on the electrolyte used). -In the small groove wind 1/8 inch magnesium ribbon (this will be your negative connection).
-In the outside wind 1/4 inch copper ribbon (this will be your positive connection.
-The battery is made out of at least 3 parts. The end caps have a hole for a bolt that holds your magnesium ribbon in place. The middle part can be connected to itself without breaking the spiral pattern in the middle. This allows you to make this battery as long as you want it to me (the longer it is the more amps you'll get).
-The diameter of the battery is 1 inch, this allows you to use standard 1 inch PVC tubing as a case for your electrolyte. Possible electrolytes that can be used are: water with alum, water with sodium bicarbonate, vinegar, plain water (lowest amperage but least corrosion for your metals).
-The 3dm file is included if you'd like to make your own changes, as always. Love and peace!

title: Ord Bot Hadron Webcam/Light Mount X-Axis Tensioner Mash Up

description.text: Here is my mash up of Ord Bot X-Axis Idler Belt Tensioner and Hadron Ord Bot Handy Cam / IP Camera holder to create a mounting arm for led panel and usb webcam for use with my Raspberry Pi running OctoPrint. I thinned down and simplified the links as I was not supporting the same amount of weight as predecessor's design. Integrated mounting bracket into the Ord Bot X-Axis Idler Belt Tensioner to avoid bolting to axis plate. Printed but not yet installed due to bolt availability. I had to drill out the holes in the hinge connections for friction free movement. Use M4x50 (or longer) and M4 nuts (press fit into nut traps) to connect links to bracket and each other. Use M5x8 bolts and t-nuts to mount bracket to X-Axis and M4x20 bolts and M4 nuts for tensioning bolts as described in predecessor's description.

description.text:
Use the excellent front cover from Walter's rigidbot LCD with this back cover to mount the LCD to the front of your makergear M2. This uses the reprap discount GLCD square form factor LCD.
I had to print walter's front LCD cover at 104% to get it to fit my LCD properly and the back should be printed at 100% to match.

author: macsboost

description.text: I use my 8X for photography as it's better than my old digital camera... but I can never hold my hands still enough and always blur the shots. Being a windows phone there is almost zero accessories! And being a maker with a 3D printer... I remedied that with this camera mount.

Will need support. I printed with the flat back down on an UP mini in white ABS. Keep in mind that the soda blasted polycarbonate of the 8X might start to wear after a while on the sliding faces... it's the price you pay for that sort of finish and probably why there's so few accessories for this phone.
Once printed, just carefully tap the tripod mounting screw into the plastic. I had no issues but you might need to reinforce this area with a quick acetone dip if you encounter layer splitting.
Prusa i3 webcam (Logitech C170) support Greg's Wade, for octoprint

This item was made to increase accuracy for guys with big hands.

Updated v2 - just uses a m3 x 8mm hex socket cap and a m3 nut.  
The other version was too long, even for my big hands. Also, it had issues allowing a forward push and thumb click, especially necessary for running or knifing.  This version was printed with a 4mm support structure and 5.5mm brim.

comments.author: alaubhan

description.text: Our pinguin Eugene :)

Whenever I do a tracking jump, I find it hard to read my wrist-mounted altimeter. I thought it'd be nice to have a chest-mounted altimeter that used LEDs as a sort of progress bar to show me exactly where I currently am in the sky. Once you get to 1000' it will switch to show altitude for landing. Altimeter can been seen in use here.

Operation
Turn on altimeter on the ground, it will set a zero altitude, and will flash a quick white light every five seconds to tell you it is on. Everything it does after will be relative to that zero altitude. Above 1000', the lights with flash cyan every two seconds. When you are 3/4 of the way between breakoff altitude and exit altitude, the lights will go through an activation sequence. After this, the altimeter is ready to jump. On the way down, the LEDs will act like a progress bar counting down to your breakoff altitude:
  • Between breakoff and pull altitude, they will flash yellow.
  • Between pull altitude and hard deck, they will flash red.
  • Below hard deck, they will remain solid red.
  • Once you reach 1000', the altimeter will switch to acting as a landing altimeter, and will show you your altitude between 1000' and 0'.
    • At 125' the LEDs will switch off. Turn the switch off and on again to re-zero for the next jump.

Default Settings
The default settings are in feet and are:
  • Exit Altitude: 13000'
  • Breakoff Altitude: 5000'
  • Pull Altitude: 4000'
  • Harddeck: 2500'
    • Make sure these are set correctly for where you are jumping and your experience level. The variables are located near the top of the Arduino code. Change the number values to what you need.
Full build instructions can be found in PDF in the Thing Files.

Parts List
  • 5v Boost Converter
  • Arduino Nano Clone
  • BMP180 Breakout Board
  • RadioShack 2 AAA Battery Holder
  • 8 WS2812 LED Strip
  • 2 1/4" x 1/8" Disc Magnets
  • Slide Switch
  • Wire
The Arduino code running the altimeter makes use of a couple different libraries these can be downloaded from the following links: Sparkfun BMP180 Library Adafruit NeoPixel Library

Miniskybot V2, a small Printbot (printable robot) for educational purposes. Features:
  • Simplified chassis
  • Marbel as cator wheel (thanks to sliptonic)
    • Battery holder screwed to the chassis
  • Compact and small
    • 3 type of wheels, for the 3 different servo horns
    • Electronics Compatible with skymega and Arduino UNO boards
    • Github:
    https://github.com/Obijuan/Miniskybot Youtube videos:

  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ybLnEIOfsBg

  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9zH0n-bU9AU
    • More information (in Spanish):
    http://www.iearobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=Miniskybot_2

• Downloaded the STL files: chassis, battery holder and wheels

Credit for this design goes to Eric K. Drexler. I merely made a printable model from the raw data that was supplied with the "nanoengineer-1" software here. Shapeways: outer shell
Shapeways: inner shell
(net cost price) For an introduction to this kind of objects which I like to call "crystolecules" or more specifically "diamondoid molecular elements" (DMEs) check out my wiki page about them The number of atoms on the outer circumference of the small axle ring is chosen to be incommensurable to the number of atoms on the inside circumference of the bushing ring (they do not divide each other well). The axle thus can't snap into the grooves of the bushing. A little bit of angular energy ripple remains but it is way smaller than the average chunk of thermal energy at room temperature info. This leads to zero static friction and very low dynamic drag (between 2000 and 100000 times less drag than movement in water! See: Superlubrication. This bearing and similar ones do not wear out in normal usage. Damage can only be inflicted by heating them near melting temperature or bombarding them with ionizing radiation (UV-rays / X-rays / gamma-rays). The 3D mesh of internal bonds is harder to damage by bond breaking radiation than biological nano"machine"elements like proteins that are essentially folded 1D chain molecules thus "crystolecules" can survive longer (I didn't use DNA for comparison here since in nature it's mainly used for data storage and neither used a structural element nor as a machine element) Exploratory engineering is the reason why one can be certain that this bearing will work although being unable to produce it yet. These kinds of parts are still far off.
If you want too see something more near term I suggest you check out the amazing recent developments in the field of "structural DNA nanotechnology" like this one:
Foresight news: Micrometer-scale structures built from DNA bricks. Organic nanorobotics IS coming. Anorganic nanorobotics will follow.
Instructions for how to create such models can be found on the instructions section of the DMSE-Tetrapod page.

See instructions for the DMSE-Tetrapod:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13786/#instructions

author: trevorl

title: Pyramid-o-mania
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This design was made to try out if the printer can handle it without support material, and the result came out pretty nice.  
It also is an interestingly looking piece of art, if I can say that. At least watching all those smaller pyramids inside the big one is kind of cool. :)  
Fun fact: There are 540 standing pyramids and 210 upside-down pyramids in this mesh, which makes a sum of 750 pyramids.

Printer:

Easy3DMaker - modded

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: Nozzle: 0.5mm

This can be printed out without support material.
Remember to use higher speed (around 60mm/s) at bridges, so they won't bend down. If you use support, only use it when you have multiple extruders, and soluable support material. Otherwise you won't be able to remove the support from inside the pyramid. You can scale it up if you want, it works with 1.5% of original size. For bigger scales I don't know, the bridges could be too large and they can bend. (Of course this does not apply when using support material) Note: It can take some time to generate its gcode. At least for me Slic3r had a hard time, I even went to eat my lunch and it was still slicing when I came back.

author: Flightcache

title: integrated suppresor for KJ Works MK 1 Ruger

description.text:
a suppressed barrel for the KJ Works/ ASG/ Evoloution Airsoft MK1 pistol / Ruger.  
designed to replace the original barrel and secured through a 3 mm tapped hole on the underside of the pistol.  
after printing the hole through the middle will need reaming if an inner barrel is to fit as the printing process isn't perfect and makes it a very tight fit.  
if you want to use this on a MK1 carbine receiver (like i do) then you need to turn one end down to fit inside the receiver as it is longer than the pistol variant. you will also have to drill and tap a new hole in the part and the receiver as the hole for fixing is in a different place.

hole at the base of the barrel needs tapping out to 3mm.
cavity at end of barrel needs filling with foam to create the suppressor
end cap needs to be glued on once cavity is filled. this will only fit the pistol variant of the KJW Ruger as the Carbine version has a longer upper receiver.

description.text:
A simple model of famous "Ayers Rock".
Based on google maps datas, which were imported in sketchup.
In Sketchup I added several planes to cut the model everey 2,5m and so I got a topographical model showing the heights. Using the sandbox tool I turned that model into a solid.
I added a base for a better starting point. On printing I cut down the objects bottom to the desired level.

Printed with 20% infill, using UM standard values.  
To get the right level, I doubled the values of the Z-axis.

title: B+ Pi Cam Ultimaker 2 timelapse harness

description.text:
The assumption is that you already have a Raspberry Pi Model B+, the Pi Camera module of your choice, any extension cable and the capture software for taking the images etc.  
This thing is a modular harness that will attach and support the Pi and the camera module onto the front or side of an Ultimaker 2. The camera can be moved into any position and rotates as well so it can look down on your print, or hanging underneath look directly at your print, front face on, or from a corner.  
It should also be noted that the focal length of the PI Cam module is about 45cm. For this reason you'll probably want to hotglue a +2.0 reading glass lens over the front of the module to get this back in the region of 20-25cm... where this camera actually sits from the center of the build plate.

For the pi you will need a Pi Frame Front, a Pi Frame Back, a hook of your choice (depending on where you'l like to situate your Pi - I'd suggest the side) and a regular (non-long) bolt. Assembly should be pretty self explanatory.  
For the camera mount you will need the pi cam mount, the mount block, the hook of your choosing (I'd suggest the front) and a long bolt.  
You then need at least 2 arm pieces to give the flexibility and a regular bolt for each. The mount block has the thread so you need to bolt through the hole in the arm into the block. The same then happens for the second arm.  
You should then press the Pi Camera Module into the camera head, there are locator pins and recesses for the components on the camera board, so it will sit flush.   
The camera head should then bolt through to the top of the last arm piece.  
I also built a lens holder for the photos instead of using hotglue, but I didn't include it in the files because chances are you will not have the same lens. You can take off 2mm of the camera head (taking you t othe mid point of the curves) and then build a 3mm plate to hold your lens. This should give enough clearance for the curved lens from a pair of reading glass.
